title: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
displayTitle: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
mobileInstruction: Click '+' to explore each case study

_items.title: Increasing online sales
_items.body:
Competing for sales in the online market is tough. There are now a large number of channels that can be used to reach potential customers including dynamic paid search, story campaigns and even direct-buy buttons that can be embedded by review websites, on blogs, and in other social media.

These all rely on real-time product data including prices and (increasingly) availability. We are seeing retailers being increasingly open with their product data, helping it reach new channels, enabling them to be more visible and competitive in the marketplace.

_items.title: Building a platform for data flows
_items.body: Amazon realised early that parts of the business that collected data and held it in silos could prevent it from realising the most value from data. Amazon also realised that it should design these services to also be available externally, enabling organisations and individuals to use the data to innovate. Amazon now provides the data infrastructure for hundreds of companies who use it to connect to their markets and grow their businesses.
_items.strapline: Building a platform for data flows

_items.title: Winning awards for ethical data practices
_items.body:
In 2019, Co-op was awarded the DatalQ Award for Best Data Ethics and Privacy Programme.

In an era where data is increasingly crucial to commercial success and customers are growing more aware of how data about them is used, this award recognises Co-op colleagues’ commitment to being trusted with the data about its members, customers, and communities, which helps ensure that the business makes informed and ethical decisions that support its values.

Co-op, which offers a diverse range of products and services, used the Open Data Institute’s Data Ethics Canvas to empower teams and help them identify and manage ethical issues when using data, while building data literacy.
_items.strapline: Winning awards for ethical data practices

title: Using data to lead creative transformation at WPP
body: To deliver creative transformation through data, we have a four-strand approach.
instruction: Click '+' to find out more about each strand

_items.title: Open
_items.body: We have built the WPP OPEN Data Catalog for our data community to access an index of data available across WPP and to share non-sensitive data. The catalog has already increased collaboration between our data talent in our creative, media and digital agencies.

_items.title: Trusted
_items.body: Creative transformation must be done in a way that maintains and boosts brand reputation and trust. With fears over AI and data being used to monitor, track and influence people we have run AI ethics workshops with 10 of our agencies and are creating guidelines and principles to be used alongside our AI Code of Conduct. These guidelines and principles will be rolled out to agencies in 2020, with the goal to embed them in everyday activities.

_items.title: Future-proofed
_items.body: To help everyone get creative through data, we will provide data literacy programmes for everyone. In addition to these modules, our AI Academy will upskill 2,500 data scientists in 2020 and the same again in 2021. Our Demystify AI programme will help upskill 25,000 of our colleagues in AI basics.

_items.title: Creatively inspiring
_items.body: We are building a cross-agency, cross-market, multi-discipline data and AI community. This group fuels our creativity through code sharing, blogs, and challenges that give us space to think about questions laterally and to tackle client problems; and helps ensure we don’t duplicate work.

title: Common barriers to achieving impact from data
displayTitle: Common barriers to achieving impact from data
body: Which of the following are common barriers to achieving impact from data?

_items.text: A lack of willingness to share data with others
No suitable technology to make use of data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data; technology and data are never in short supply. The following section introduces the Open Data Institutes theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data; technology and data are never in short supply. The following section introduces the Open Data Institutes theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

title: Where data sits in our landscape
displayTitle: Where data sits in our landscape
body:
We want data to motivate, inspire and to grow our creativity to help deliver high-quality products for our clients. Our clients pay for high-quality data outputs, not for huge data lakes which become too big and cumbersome to maintain.

“Through 2022, over 80% of data lake projects will fail to deliver value. Finding, inventorying and curating data will prove to be the biggest inhibitor to analytics and data science success.” - Gartner, September 2019

WPP is not in the business of buying, collecting and storing huge swathes of irrelevant data, especially when a lot of data is already available.

“Data increases in value the more it is connected” - ODI 2017

We want to enable our community to discover new sources of high-quality data – both internally and externally – we  created the WPP OPEN Data catalog. The catalog provides an index of data available across WPP and enables our community to share non-sensitive data. The catalog has already increased collaboration between our data talent across our creative, media and digital agencies.

title: The data landscape
body:
Data is moving from being scarce and difficult to process to being abundant and easy to use.

However, to realise the full benefits that data can bring, businesses must understand the ‘data landscape’.

This module introduces:

  • Where data sits in our landscape
  • How value is created from data
  • Common barriers that prevent the full value of data being realised
  • The advantages of being more open and trusted with data
  • How WPP is using data to lead creative transformation

_graphic.attribution: Adapted from the Open Data Institute's theory of change [CC-BY-SA]

title: Where next?
body:
To help everyone discover more about how WPP is using data, there are three additional modules available, each designed to help you discover more on each strand:

Getting value from data: Creative inspiration and more…

Find out more about how data can be collected, shared and used not just for creative inspiration but also to help realise other benefits.

Being trusted with data

We believe that clients should be able to rely on our data expertise to deliver creative transformation because they trust us to be responsible with data; to hold ourselves accountable for the data-driven decisions we are making; and to do our best to protect our clients. This module looks at what mechanisms need to be in place to ensure we are trusted to be responsible with data.

Working with data

We know data is imperfect and it’s only as good as the questions you ask of it – good design is imperative. This module introduces some of the key aspects involved in working with data that help us ensure data is well managed and can be used to generate transformative results.

title: Common barriers (1): Hoarding data
body:
One of the biggest challenges to realising the full value of data is the lack of cultural willingness to share data. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the oil field’.

The oil field is a scenario where: owning data; having as much data as possible in one place; trying to know everything about everyone and then maintaining the inevitable degradation of these datasets – is killing the return on investment (and the fun!) when working with  data, and it’s not the only way!

Such approaches lead to a closed (or walled garden) environment which can greatly reduce innovation capabilities.

To overcome this barrier, organisations should support an open culture as much as possible. During challenging times it is especially important to realise the benefits of working with others, sharing insights and innovating together.

Building a data catalog that we can all use helps ensure variety is our data superpower. It also helps to prevent hoarding and the inevitable associated degradation of data.

title: Data variety is our superpower
body:
Data is both a source of inspiration and a material used in the development of creative products. We can use data to help shape and refine what we create, reach new markets, drive engagement and deliver emotional experiences that connect consumers to our brands.

This superpower can only be activated when the right data is collected and made available to those who need it.

At WPP we want our data talent to spend as much time as possible using data creatively, not having to find and obtain access to data. This is why we have created the WPP Open Data catalog. The catalog will enable everyone to list, discover and explore relevant data that is available from the community as well as external sources.

Of course, we have access to all the usual datasets; audience data, client data, brand data, transactional data, market data, campaign data, creative and media data and operational data.

title: Creating impact with data
body:
Value is created when we collect, manage and share data in ways that support creative transformation.

For example, recently we have seen how data can be used to: deliver £14m of sales for a large supermarket chain; demonstrate how nearly all modern music has roots in Tennessee; and create dynamic and unique brand experiences for music venues. You can find out more about these and other case studies in the next module.

Clients should be able to rely on our data expertise to deliver creative transformation because they trust us: to be responsible with data; to hold ourselves accountable for the data-driven decisions we are making; and to do our best to protect our clients.

To realise the value of data we need to develop the culture, capabilities and infrastructure that help ensure data is not siloed, and enable it to be used alongside other data.

title: Common barriers (2): Fearing data
body:
If data is unused and unloved, it will degrade and could potentially lead to security risks, reputational and brand damage. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the wasteland’.

The wasteland is most prevalent in situations where unaddressed fears arising from legitimate concerns – such as who has access to data and how it might be used – prevent any benefits being realised.

The ODI recommends putting in place practices that ensure the way data is collected and used is trustworthy and just.

To help address these fears WPP Open is developing a set of Data Ethics Principles and Guidelines that will be rolled out in each agency to ensure there is equity around who accesses, uses and benefits from data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Using data for creative transformation
body:
Our clients pay for high-quality data products and services that deliver value: value that is created by releasing data from silos and putting it to work.

This module explores how data:

  • inspires and informs the creative process
  • helps us reach new markets and audiences
  • provides new insights into markets, consumers and brands
  • makes a greater impact when accessed, used and shared more effectively
  • makes our work more efficient and gets better results for our clients.

Used in creative ways, data can spark emotions. This helps improve the engagement people have with data, reducing fear and increasing intrigue.

When using data creatively an essential part of the process is deciding how data should be processed and how the outputs should be shared. Data impacts all areas of our lives but this is often difficult to represent and demystify. Collaboration between artists, creatives and technical experts, such as data scientists can help. These collaborations can lead to new creative work, including artworks, poetry and music.

_items.title: Data as culture
_items.body:
The ODI’s Data as Culture art programme engages new and diverse audiences with work by artists who critically and materially explore data, code and network culture.

Mr Gee’s poems offer us a way through the blur and noise of overwhelming volumes of data.

Alistair Gentry’s “DoxBox Trustbot” helps us consider the trustworthiness of those we share data with, and how many data versions of ourselves we create online.

_items.title: Turning data into unique logos
_items.body: The AKQA logo generator for KAOS transformed data and sound into unique versions of the Las Vegas nightclub’s logo. The generator combined data with music to add a unique, personalised touch to every music event and fan interaction.

_items.title: Using data to inspire content
_items.body: Unscripted, Wunderman Thompson’s campaign for BT, combined sports data with analytics to write the first AI-inspired script for a football season. Before a ball was kicked the campaign fuelled the debate between players, pundits and fans about the accuracy of this digital crystal ball, and the season to come. The campaign gained 137 million media impressions and grew subscriptions for BT Sport with 100% more fans than the previous season.

displayTitle: Data in action: reaching new markets and audiences

Data serves as a material and inspiration for creative work. We also need to data to inform how we evolve ideas into content and campaigns that make an impact for our clients. 

Find our how in the video below.

displayTitle: Read more: reaching new markets and audiences

_items.title: Generating creative insights for a brand
_items.body:
A variety of data sources, both internal and external can be used to better understand the relationships between markets, brands and consumers.

An experiment in data-informed creativity helped Kantar Consulting and Wunderman identify a new way to raise the profile of Children’s IKEA by weaving multiple data sources together. They analysed 50m rows of data to find out what parents most care about and identified that ‘behaviour and development’ was high on the list, in second place. They also established that 50% of parents struggle for ideas that encourage creative play. So, IKEA Toybox was created, an augmented-reality driven app that inspires recycling boxes.
_items.strapline: Generating creative insights for a brand

_items.title: Reaching new markets
_items.body:
When a WPP customer wants to increase the reach of their brand and generate sales, data about people provides insights that make strategy and planning decisions more effective.

MediaCom used data to build an ‘intent-to-purchase score’ for Shell to help inform millions of prospects. They started by looking at data covering purchase ‘intent signals’ for consumers in China and the US. These signals were aggregated into a single intent-to-purchase score that was used to target customers. For the first time, Shell was able to target globally through media and messaging for every product, based on a customer’s actual intent to purchase.

_items.title: Reaching new audiences
_items.body:
Skillfully connected and processed, data becomes the infrastructure of a campaign – powering both creatives and personalised consumer experiences. 

VMLY&R’s music genealogy engine searches, then combines billions of data points and text articles, in real-time, to show an artist’s musical chain of influence back to Tennessee – in less than six degrees of separation. For the first time, a new generation of fans could trace their favourite artists' influences to modern American music’s Tennessee roots. Visitors to the Rolling Stone website searched 431 million connections, resulting in a 9.8% increase in people travelling to Tennessee.

They don’t have permission to use data
Data is in siloes or of poor quality so it can’t be used effectively

This also applies to the data we work with at WPP. When we share data more widely, for example by listing datasets on the WPP OPEN Data catalog, we open up the potential for other people to use our data in creative ways.

title: Getting connected
body:
“A single piece of data only becomes useful – and therefore valuable – once combined with other data.”

-- The ODI

title: Data in action: getting connected
body: Many organisations struggle to use data effectively. Data is often in siloes, is of insufficient quality or is accessed and used inefficiently by internal teams, who may have to resort to tactics like scraping data manually from a website. Helping a client better access, use and share their data creates strategic value for their business, achieving better returns from a previously underused resource. It also increases innovation across the business and improves the brand reputation of the originators of the work.
instruction: Find out more in the case studies below:

_items.title: Data creates more value when it’s shared
_items.body:
OpenActive is a community-led initiative setting standards for data use and publication in the leisure industry, to help people get active. Everyone Active, a leisure centre operator, started to publish open data about classes and facilities.

This, in turn, enabled MoveGB a fitness search and subscription app to include Everyone Active’s products in its offering. Through this one partnership, EveryoneActive gained 11,500 customers, 95% of whom had never been members before.
_items.strapline: Data creates more value when it’s shared

_items.title: Helping existing clients extract better value from their data through effective data management
_items.body: John Lewis wanted to increase product coverage and visibility in Google Paid Search campaigns and to increase the return on investment on its Google spend. Wunderman Thompson’s Commerce Data Management team set up product feed technology to extract product data from the retailer’s website. They then used this data to build campaigns for John Lewis and to set automated business rules. As a result, return on investment in paid search increased by 300% and conversions by 250%.
_items.strapline: Helping existing clients extract better value from their data through effective data management

_items.title: Generating value through shared work [and data]
_items.body: The Mirum data team explored the WPP OPEN Data catalog for relevant datasets and to suggest new ones based on their client’s needs. Two datasets were used to develop decision trees and neural networks. These were documented and the Mirum team shared the documentation on the Wunderman Thompson data science Slack channel. The learnings from the decision tree exercise were applied to a decision tree project for United Healthcare.
_items.strapline: Generating value through shared work [and data]

title: Data in action: insights, refinement and targeted marketing
displayTitle: Data in action: insights, refinement and targeted marketing

_items.title: Generating insights
_items.body: How can we emotionally engage consumers with a petrol brand, when over 50% of petrol consumption is spontaneous and based on geographic convenience?  Previous ad targeting focused on demographics and behaviour. Through in-depth data mining combined with consumer research, Acceleration generated new insights into the personal, emotional needs that drive petrol purchases. These insights formed the basis for promoting more relevant content to consumers.

_items.title: Finding efficiencies
_items.body: In 2017, Wunderman Thompson generated an incremental $65m in premiums while saving over $7.5min marketing expense for a US-based life insurer. Audience data was analysed to develop targeting schemes that were dynamically adapted based on performance. This helped maximise the cost per lead.

_items.title: Targeted marketing
_items.body: Tesco & MediaCom used data-informed decision making to guide targeting for localised meat campaigns in the UK. Data indicated that income and cost per kilogram was the driving force behind when lamb was purchased, as an alternative to chicken or pork. This led to the creation of ‘Meat Matrix’ and the launch of a local and personal Easter trading campaign. Specific deals were targeted by postcodes and regions, driving £14m of added sales.

title: Summary
body:
Our clients pay for high-quality data products and services that deliver value. Value that is created by releasing data from silos and putting it to work.

Data is both a source of inspiration and a material used in the development of creative products. We can use data to help shape and refine what we create, provide actionable insights, and help us find ways to improve how we operate and deliver services. 

In this module we have seen how data can build brands, increase return on investment and connect emotionally with customers. This helps us to build trust in our work, but trust is fragile and we must ensure that we use data in ways that maintain and build trust. 

As we will see in the next module, building trust means engaging in two-way conversations with audiences about the challenges and limitations of data-informed marketing and advertising. Our clients should be able to trust how we work with and manage data. Consumers should be able to trust how we use data to shape creative work and run influential campaigns.

title: Being trusted with data
body:
WPP recognises its obligations to its stakeholders including shareowners, clients, its own people, suppliers and consumers. 

This module looks at what mechanisms need to be in place to ensure we are trusted to be responsible with data.

Specifically, this module looks at the importance of: 

  • respecting the rights of organisations and individuals
  • being transparent with how data is collected, shared and used
  • data ethics.

title: Is all data on the web free to use?
displayTitle: Is all data on the web free to use?
body: All data available on the web is open and free to use. True or false?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that anyone is free to use that data. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use, unless it is published under an open licence.

The same is true for data. 

Our code of conduct states that we must treat data in accordance with all applicable laws, regulations and treaties. 

We must respect both the rights of data owners and also any individuals the data may be about.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that anyone is free to use that data. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use, unless it is published under an open licence.

The same is true for data. 

Our code of conduct states that we must treat data in accordance with all applicable laws, regulations and treaties. 

We must respect both the rights of data owners and also any individuals the data may be about.

title: Respecting rights of data subjects
body:
As well as respecting the rights of data owners, we must also respect the rights of data subjects: the people the data is about. 

Data security and privacy are increasingly high-profile topics for regulators, consumers and our clients.

We know that data about consumers can be used as a powerful tool to drive sales, but we are also committed to being transparent with consumers about how data about them is collected, used and shared. 

To learn more about data privacy and rights we recommend looking at the WPP Data Code of Conduct, ethics statements and our WPP guidelines and principles. Several agencies also offer client consultancy and you can find out more here.

title: Managing bias in data
body:
Ethical data challenges are often faced as a result of data being biased, for example only containing data relating to certain demographics of geographic areas. 

What can you do to help reduce the risk of biased data leading to unethical results?

_items.text: Be open about the biases and limitations of the data
Collect a wider variety of data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Having more data or not using the data are not always solutions to ethical challenges. Data variety is our superpower and this coupled with being open about the limitations in the data will help us be more trusted with data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Having more data or not using the data are not always solutions to ethical challenges. Data variety is our superpower and this coupled with being open about the limitations in the data will help us be more trusted with data.

title: Case studies in data ethics
body: Explore the case studies below to find out how even non-personal data can lead to inequitable and unethical outcomes.

_items.title: Case study 1: PokemonGo! A real-world game
_items.body: Within days of the popular augmented reality game PokemonGo being released many felt excluded. It was discovered that many areas were deprived of PokeStops and these appeared to be in lower-income and predominantly ethnic minority neighbourhoods. Investigations found that PokeStops had been crowdsourced from a previous game called ‘Ingress’ which was primarily played by people from white and higher-income neighbourhoods This limitation in the data led to accusations of bias, even though the data was not personal data.

_items.title: Case study 2: Automated consumer profiling - car insurance
_items.body: A 2018 investigation in the UK found that people with the first name ‘Mohammed’ were charged up to £1,000 more to insure their cars than someone with the first name ‘John’. The investigation compared insurance quotes that contained exactly the same details for everything but first name. They discovered that the algorithms that calculate insurance quotes appear to correlate first names with level of risk. Although the exact reason for this is not known, experts suspect that the source data used by the decision-making system  does not contain a wide variety of data for certain names, and therefore makes  decisions based on a limited number of existing profiles with the same name. Remember, data variety is our superpower.

_items.title: Case study 3: Good Samaritan – suicidal tweets
_items.body: A charity developed a tool that analysed the sentiment of a user’s tweets, assessed whether they are suicidal and alerted friends. While this is an admirable project and a potentially life-saving tool, it ultimately proved to be both illegal, inaccurate and too controversial. Assessing someone's mental state means you are dealing with sensitive personal data that should not simply be broadcast to friends without careful consideration. We also know from our work with Investec on #MoreThanData, that using data to profile individuals, as opposed to groups, is often inaccurate and leads to breakdown in trust.

title: Question 1
body: We should be transparent with everyone about what data we hold, how it is used and the limitations of the data and its use. True or false?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

We have a responsibility to be transparent to society and our clients about how we use data. We should be transparent about its use and consider its impact on our people, clients, investors, partners, the wider community and the environment.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

We have a responsibility to be transparent to society and our clients about how we use data. We should be transparent about its use and consider its impact on our people, clients, investors, partners, the wider community and the environment.

title: Different types of data in the WPP Open Data Catalog
body: The different types of data are clearly tagged in the WPP Open Data Catalog. On a dataset page there is a “Sensitivity/Restricted” section under “More information”. Open data is labelled with tags such as “Open source” or “Public” and is available to everyone, even those outside of WPP. Other datasets are tagged as “WPP only” or “Restricted”.

title: Question 2
body: The way AI systems work should be kept secret. True or false?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data gathering, development processes and algorithms should be documented to ensure that AI systems are traceable and auditable. 

While this might sound like it results in an organisation giving away its secrets, that is not the intention of such statements. The aim is to help organisations build trust with their clients. It is also perfectly possible to achieve this without losing any commercial advantage, in fact openness and transparency grow commercial advantage.  

You can even have fun with this process, as demonstrated by Google who help users to understand how their search rankings work with the aid of PigeonRank, a system for ranking web pages developed by Google founders.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data gathering, development processes and algorithms should be documented to ensure that AI systems are traceable and auditable. 

While this might sound like it results in an organisation giving away its secrets, that is not the intention of such statements. The aim is to help organisations build trust with their clients. It is also perfectly possible to achieve this without losing any commercial advantage, in fact openness and transparency grow commercial advantage.  

You can even have fun with this process, as demonstrated by Google who help users to understand how their search rankings work with the aid of PigeonRank, a system for ranking web pages developed by Google founders.

title: Question 3
body: We only need to be concerned with ethics, equality and human rights when processing personal data. True or false?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data collection, use or sharing – regardless of whether the data is personal – should be designed and operated to be compatible with human rights and freedoms; to empower people in their work at WPP and across the group; and to allow for human choice.

body: Whose responsibility is it to ensure we are ethical with data?

The legal, data security and privacy teams

Being ethical with data at WPP is everyone’s responsibility. We encourage our people to challenge data use and speak up if they have a concern.

title: Question 4
body: New AI systems tout the ability for machines to learn from data and make decisions autonomously. Who is responsible for the decisions these systems make?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

We believe humans are always responsible for decisions, regardless of the use of AI or other algorithms. Humans should always be in the loop. We acknowledge our responsibility to understand both the limitations and possibilities of data and to ensure that any processing is proportionate to our needs. Keeping humans in the loop is essential to preserve creativity, understand limitations and reduce risk.

title: Identifying and managing ethical concerns
instruction: Explore the four key areas below

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
• What data do you need; is it available?
  • Does the data have limitations, gaps, inconsistencies or biases?
  • Are there any existing ethical or legislative contexts you need to consider?
  • Are there any issues with data rights that need to be addressed?

_items.title: Impact
_items.body:
• What are you trying to achieve by collecting, sharing or using data?
  • What positive impacts will there be?
  • What negative impact might there be?
  • How will you minimise negative impact?

_items.title: Engagement
_items.body:
• How do you ensure you are as open as possible about this project?
  • How will you communicate with people?
  • How will you allow people to engage if they have concerns?
  • Will you be publishing data and/or models as part of this process?

_items.title: Process
_items.body:
• How will systems and processes support the ethical practices?
  • How often will these be reviewed?
  • How will ongoing data ethics issues be measured, monitored, discussed and actioned?
  • Who will be responsible for the integration and who must be involved?

title: Summary
body:
WPP recognises its obligations to its stakeholders including shareowners, clients, its own people, suppliers and consumers. 

We must respect and protect the rights of organisations and individuals alike and we must do this in a way that means that data is used not only lawfully but ethically.

Find out more about our codes of practice and ethical frameworks on the community pages, where you can also find our how to join the community and ask for help.

title: Engaging consumers in conversations about trust
displayTitle: Engaging consumers in conversations about trust
body: In their #MoreThanData campaign Investec & Wunderman Thompson Africa used data to show the limitations of data. By acknowledging the concerns about data and engaging in genuine two-way conversations, Investec was able to build a position of trust about data for their brand that goes beyond the standard statements about data trustworthiness used by many brands.
instruction: Watch the video to discover more.

title: Respecting the rights of data owners
displayTitle: Respecting the rights of data owners
body:
Owning data – having as much data as possible in one place, trying to know everything about everyone – is not only a problem in terms of data management, it also risks infringing rights. 

To help explain this complex landscape, the Open Data Institute has produced the Data Spectrum which neatly illustrates the different types of data you will find in the WPP catalogue.
instruction: Click on the pins to find out more about each type of data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Closed / Limited data
_items.body:
Closed data covers data that is only available to a few individuals. Data should be closed if it is necessary to protect people from harm, and covers things such as sensitive legal documents, employment contracts and personal health records. 

Examples of closed data in WPP include: HR records and appraisal documents.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Shared data
_items.body:
Shared data is the largest category and covers everything from medical research data to social network data. In this category, there are often restrictions on who can access and use the data.

Examples of shared data in WPP include: BrandZ Data (WPP only),  WPP Data Survey - Summary of Service Providers (restricted).

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Open / Public data
_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Companies and governments have been increasingly publishing open data and reaping the benefits of the ecosystems the data supports. 


Examples of open data in WPP include: Corporate messaging (public), Future of Business Survey (public).

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
